attributes.action: Request an immediate end to the trade in Ivory from Zimbabwe, Botswana, South Africa & Namibia
attributes.action_prefix: We the undersigned petition the Prime Minister to
attributes.background:
In 1989 the trade in Ivory was outlawed.
 
In 1997, CITES agreed to partially lift the ban, down-listing the status of elephants in Botswana, Zimbabwe and Namibia so that those countries could export ivory stockpiles in a one-time sale to Japan.
 
In 2000, South Africa, Namibia, Botswana and Zimbabwe were permitted to down-list their elephant populations.
 
We are extremely concerned about the potential for even limited ivory sales to lead to the widespread slaughter of elephants. 
Many African countries are ill-equipped to meet basic anti poaching requirements. In addition, most African countries do not yet have the law enforcement or legal framework to effectively fight poaching and control the ivory trade. 
 
The trade of ivory from African elephants has also put tremendous pressure on Asian elephants, as only the males have tusks. In one nature reserve in India, there are 400 female elephants but only four adult males.
 
The ivory trade should not be allowed to continue.
